meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>public</kanji> <kanji>announcement</kanji> is a <vocabulary>public notice</vocabulary>.

公告 looks and sounds a lot like 広告, but the meanings are different. You might remember 広告 is for advertisements, but 公告 here is for the kind of official statements that companies or governments put out for the public, especially shareholders, creditors, or other stakeholders.

You can remember 公告 is a public notice because the kanji for "public" is 公, and it's not covered by a canopy like the other one. It's uncovered, all out in the open for everyone to see — public!

The <kanji>law</kanji> of <kanji>move</kanji>ment is governed by <vocabulary>rhythm</vocabulary>. Imagine moving around to a boss beat. As you move, you start to feel the rhythm in your step. Go ahead and walk around your room and feel this rhythm. 

Note that リズム is a much more common word to use for "rhythm," but you may see the kanji version sometimes in formal writing. One thing you will see more often is 律動的 which means "rhythmic."

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. Notice how it shares its reading with 蓄える and its kanji with 貯める? It also has a similar meaning — <vocabulary>to set aside</vocabulary>.

Note that 貯える is less common in modern writing, and often feels a little old-fashioned. But you might still see it in contexts where it means <vocabulary>to store up</vocabulary> food and supplies for future needs (like 蓄える) or <vocabulary>to save up</vocabulary> money (like 貯める).

Here, 歳 means <kanji>year</kanji> and 暮 comes from 暮れる (to end). So 歳暮 literally means "end of the year," but in modern Japanese, this almost always refers to a <vocabulary>year-end gift</vocabulary>, which is basically a way to say thanks before the year wraps up.

歳暮 is almost always used with the honorific お, as in お歳暮. It's a formal gift, like nicely-wrapped boxed sweets or coffee sent to bosses, clients, or people who have helped you during the year.

A <kanji>horse riding</kanji> <kanji>horse</kanji> is what you need for <vocabulary>riding a horse</vocabulary>.

This is a formal word and it’s typically used at the beginning of compounds where you'll see it translated as things like <vocabulary>mounted</vocabulary>, as in "mounted police," or <vocabulary>equestrian</vocabulary>, as in “equestrian peoples.” It's working like an adjective there, but it's still a noun in Japanese.
A <kanji>horse riding</kanji> <kanji>soldier</kanji> is a member of the <vocabulary>cavalry</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>mulberry</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji> is a <vocabulary>mulberry field</vocabulary>.

Based on an old belief that lightning does not strike mulberry fields, 桑原 (often recited twice, as in "桑原桑原") can also be used as a charm to ward off undesirable events, though it's pretty old-fashioned.

Apart from that use, 桑原 now mainly refers to the family name <vocabulary>Kuwabara</vocabulary>, like one of the main protagonists of the anime and manga series 幽遊白書.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: The Consort Of The Crown Prince
The Wife Of The Crown Prince

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 皇太子 is "crown prince"? Well, when a crown prince gets married his royal consort is the <vocabulary>crown princess</vocabulary>.

皇太子妃 specifically refers to the wife of the Crown Prince, rather than a woman who is the heir to the throne herself. Technically speaking, she is a <vocabulary>crown princess consort</vocabulary>.
溶かす is "to melt something" and that makes 溶ける <vocabulary>to melt</vocabulary> (where something just melts, and you're not doing the melting).

Someone who is <kanji>bad</kanji> but also <kanji>clever</kanji> (賢い) is someone who is using their cleverness for evil. When you refer to clever evil people, usually you describe them not as "clever" but as <vocabulary>devious</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>cunning</vocabulary>, or other things.
If 輝く is "to shine" or "to glitter" think about the noun version of this. This would be <vocabulary>radiance</vocabulary>. Radiance can come in the form of shining and glittering.

The meaning is the same as the kanji's meaning, <kanji>crab</kanji>. If you know this word, and you know the word 鰐 as well... then, well, you know something, though I'm not sure what that something is.

The great <kanji>alligator</kanji>! This can mean both <vocabulary>alligator</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>crocodile</vocabulary>, because really, they're not so different, are they? No crabigator, that's for sure.

<kanji>Gloom</kanji> <kanji>pottery</kanji> is... well, it's <vocabulary>gloomy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>depressing</vocabulary>!

This word can also mean <vocabulary>annoying</vocabulary>. If something or someone always makes you feel gloomy, you'll probably think it's annoying, right?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be <vocabulary>peak</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>ridge</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Take along</kanji> this <kanji>summit</kanji> and move it across a range, visiting more summits. One summit after another you take the summit along to. By covering this many summits, you notice there's a string of mountains. This is a <vocabulary>mountain range</vocabulary>!
You're so <kanji>adept</kanji>! That makes you <vocabulary>adept</vocabulary> at that thing. <vocabulary>Skillful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>clever</vocabulary> are other ways to do it too.

Something that is <kanji>adept</kanji> but <kanji>peculiar</kanji> in how adept it is would have to be something truly <vocabulary>clever</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ingenious</vocabulary>. Like a clever scam or trick.

巧妙 is typically used to describe deceptive actions, techniques, or methods that are not only <vocabulary>skillful</vocabulary> but also somewhat sly or crafty. It indicates a level of sophistication, often involving clever scheming or manipulation.
A <kanji>wind</kanji> that is <kanji>wicked</kanji> comes and blows on you. It's so cold, and ends up getting you sick. You now have a <vocabulary>cold</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>wicked</kanji> <kanji>devil</kanji>! Ugh, I hate those things. They're always a <vocabulary>hindrance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>intrusion</vocabulary>. Just imagine a wicked devil hanging out in your house, eating your food, and sleeping on your bed. What a hindrance.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Look <kanji>below</kanji> you. These things carry your <kanji>burdensome</kanji> weight. All of it. These are the shoes you wear, though in this case they are specifically <vocabulary>geta</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>Japanese wooden clogs</vocabulary>. The clogs themselves are kind of burdensome and hard to wear too, actually, so you can think of it that way as well.

If something is <kanji>burdensome</kanji> to the <kanji>eye</kanji> (when you look at it), you know that that thing is <vocabulary>not good</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hopeless</vocabulary>. Just look at that burdensome thing with your eye. This can also mean <vocabulary>not allowed</vocabulary>. Parents say this to their kids all the time.

<kanji>Nothing</kanji> but <kanji>burdensome</kanji>. That's all you get out of doing this task. The <vocabulary>futility</vocabulary> of it is ridiculous. The <vocabulary>uselessness</vocabulary> is huge.

A <kanji>sudden</kanji> <kanji>stab</kanji> is <vocabulary>abrupt</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>unexpected</vocabulary>. Quick, dodge!!

唐突 describes sudden actions or events that catch people off guard.
The <kanji>law</kanji> <kanji>courts</kanji> are the <vocabulary>court</vocabulary>s you visit to get law distributed. The room in which you do this in is a <vocabulary>courtroom</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Shinto shrine</kanji> <kanji>courts</kanji> are the courts of the Shinto shrines. Shinto is often associated with the emperor, which is why this the <vocabulary>imperial court</vocabulary>. <vocabulary>Royal court</vocabulary> will do as well.

A <kanji>name</kanji> <kanji>record book</kanji> is a book that contains names. That is a <vocabulary>register of names</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>list of names</vocabulary>. Is your name on the list?

A <kanji>notebook</kanji> that is also a <kanji>record book</kanji> is an <vocabulary>account book</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>register</vocabulary>, showing the records of all the transactions that have gone through.

You want people to <kanji>express</kanji> how they feel about you in a <kanji>clear</kanji> manner, so you demand they give you <vocabulary>public acknowledgement</vocabulary>. You want clear, concise <vocabulary>public recognition</vocabulary> for all of your amazing talents, skills, and for reaching level 50 of WaniKani. Maybe they'll throw you a parade!
<kanji>Comic</kanji> <kanji>drawing</kanji>s are <vocabulary>manga</vocabulary>, a.k.a. <vocabulary>Japanese comics</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>comic</kanji> <kanji>talent</kanji>! And not just one, but two comic talents, because this means a <vocabulary>comic dialogue</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>comedy double act</vocabulary>. 

More specifically, 漫才 refers to a double act that features a "funny man" (ボケ) and "straight man" (ツッコミ) in a comic dialogue routine. 漫才 is one of the most popular forms of comedy in Japan.

When you <kanji>revise</kanji> something to make it <kanji>correct</kanji> you are doing a <vocabulary>correction</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>revision</vocabulary>.

訂正 refers to officially correcting mistakes in written or spoken content, like documents, reports, or statements. It can describe both the act of correcting and the correction itself.
The <kanji>renew</kanji>ed and <kanji>revise</kanji>d <kanji>edition</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>revised edition</vocabulary>.
I need to <kanji>consult</kanji> you on this <kanji>problem</kanji>, if I could. I have a <vocabulary>question</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>enquiry</vocabulary> I'd like to ask you.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>consult</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to consult with</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to discuss</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>inscription</kanji> is the feeling one gets when something so strong happens that it's like the feeling gets inscribed into your soul. This is something that left a very <vocabulary>deep impression</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>inscription</kanji>'s <kanji>pattern</kanji> shows what <vocabulary>brand</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>make</vocabulary> this item is. If the pattern of the inscription is an apple, you'll know the brand is Apple. If it's a Window, you know it's Microsoft. Etc.

You look at this <kanji>inscription</kanji> then you look at that <kanji>inscription</kanji> and you notice that <vocabulary>each</vocabulary> one is an <vocabulary>individual</vocabulary> inscription.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The <kanji>embankment</kanji> <kanji>prevent</kanji>s the water from going over the edge. It's an <vocabulary>embankment</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>drift</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to drift</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to waft</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Drifting</kanji> down the <kanji>stream</kanji>. Something that is doing this is <vocabulary>drifting</vocabulary>. It could also be the <vocabulary>drift</vocabulary> of something.

Something has <kanji>drift</kanji>ed to the point where it has <kanji>arrive</kanji>d. Where do drifting things arrive? They arrive on shore (as they drift on top of water). That makes this word <vocabulary>drifting ashore</vocabulary>.
When you <kanji>flip</kanji> your <kanji>idea</kanji> of something, you're changing how you think about it. That's why this word is <vocabulary>change one's mind</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Flip</kanji> the <kanji>translation</kanji> of a word from one language to another. That is the <vocabulary>translation</vocabulary> of that word (or phrase, etc.).

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. While the kanji means <kanji>flip</kanji>, the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to billow</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to flutter</vocabulary>, as in some kind of material (maybe a dress or a flag) billowing or fluttering in the wind. It can also mean <vocabulary>to suddenly change</vocabulary> your mind, or your attitude, etc.

<kanji>Rut</kanji> <kanji>traces</kanji> left in the road are <vocabulary>track</vocabulary>s that mark the <vocabulary>trajectory</vocabulary> of a vehicle’s wheels.

This can also be used figuratively to refer to leaving or following some sort of trace, or to describe someone’s or something’s trajectory, among other things.

A <kanji>rut</kanji> in the <kanji>road</kanji> is for some reason an <vocabulary>orbit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>trajectory</vocabulary>. Maybe imagine a big ol' rut in the road. You drive at it at very high speeds, hit it, and fly into the sky at a <vocabulary>trajectory</vocabulary> that will send you into <vocabulary>orbit</vocabulary>. Now you're up in space, circling the earth, wishing you didn't drive so fast.
The <kanji>emperor</kanji> <kanji>empress</kanji> is the emperor's wife. That's the <vocabulary>Japanese Empress</vocabulary>, specifically, since 皇 usually refers to the Japanese emperor.
My <kanji>interest</kanji> is <kanji>stirred up</kanji>! I'm feeling <vocabulary>excitement</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>stimulation</vocabulary> from all this stirring up, in fact!

I'm getting all <kanji>stirred up</kanji>, which has caused me to <kanji>wake up</kanji> (figuratively). I'm <vocabulary>rousing</vocabulary> myself to tackle this challenge!

奮起 is a formal word for <vocabulary>rousing someone</vocabulary> or oneself to action in challenging situations. It describes a moment when someone decides to gather their strength and face a task or problem head-on.

If you see the kanji <kanji>restaurant</kanji> attached to a place name, there's a good chance that it's a <vocabulary>restaurant</vocabulary>, especially a <vocabulary>traditional Japanese restaurant</vocabulary>. It also crops up on the end of other places where you can rest, like <vocabulary>inn</vocabulary>s, those traditional <vocabulary>pavilion</vocabulary>s you see in Japanese parks and temple grounds, and <vocabulary>tea house</vocabulary>s.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>look up to</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to look up at</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to look up to</vocabulary>.

Someone tries to make you <kanji>look up to</kanji> them... twice. That's too many times to look up to someone. When this happens, this person must be <vocabulary>pompous</vocabulary>.

仰々しい is a relatively formal word often used to describe something that feels <vocabulary>exaggerated</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>excessively grand</vocabulary>. It can refer to a speech, ceremony, or behavior that comes across as overly formal, showy, or dramatic.
I <kanji>look up to</kanji> <kanji>heaven</kanji>, and I am <vocabulary>taken aback</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>amazed</vocabulary> by it. It's just so amazing.
I <kanji>believe</kanji> and <kanji>look up to</kanji> a higher power, for I have <vocabulary>religious faith</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>chief</kanji> of this district is that guy, the <vocabulary>count</vocabulary>. He's also the <vocabulary>earl</vocabulary> of another district, and the <vocabulary>chief</vocabulary> of yet another.

Who is the <kanji>chief</kanji> <kanji>mother</kanji>? That's your <vocabulary>aunt</vocabulary>. And this aunt is the older sister of your mom or dad because she is the chief mother. An aunt who is a younger sister of your parent is 叔母, which is another word for "aunt" you already know!
Something you do accidentally is hopefully something you do occasionally or once in a while. Also note that this word is usually written in hiragana. You'll only occasionally see it in kanji.

Something that happened <kanji>accidentally</kanji> by <kanji>nature</kanji> probably happened <vocabulary>by chance</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unexpectedly</vocabulary>. It was just a <vocabulary>coincidence</vocabulary>!

<kanji>Distribute</kanji> yourself <kanji>accidentally</kanji> to <kanji>someone</kanji>. That person ended up becoming your <vocabulary>spouse</vocabulary>. You distributed yourself to one person a little too much, it seems.

The <kanji>eddy</kanji> <kanji>river</kanji> isn't so much a thing as it is a famous place. We're talking about <vocabulary>Yodogawa</vocabulary>. It might be better to look at the reading to learn the meaning. Look up this Osaka Prefecture river if you'd like more info.
An <kanji>old</kanji> <kanji>tomb</kanji> is an <vocabulary>ancient tomb</vocabulary>. They're mostly from the <vocabulary>Kofun</vocabulary> period, and indeed that's where the period gets its name.
A <kanji>tomb</kanji> <kanji>grave</kanji> is a <vocabulary>grave</vocabulary>... or it could be a <vocabulary>tomb</vocabulary>. Or maybe both.
It's so <kanji>robust</kanji> and <kanji>big</kanji>! Things like this are <vocabulary>magnificent</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>grand</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>epic</vocabulary>!
Your <kanji>robust</kanji> <kanji>year</kanji>s are the best years of your life! This is the <vocabulary>prime of life</vocabulary>.

You want to make someone feel <kanji>robust</kanji> when they <kanji>go</kanji> away somewhere, so you give them a <vocabulary>send-off</vocabulary>. It's just a nice way to say <vocabulary>farewell</vocabulary>!

壮行 is usually for celebratory send-offs and appears in words like 壮行会 (farewell party) or 壮行式 (pep rally).
The kanji refers to a <kanji>bundle</kanji>, but this refers to a <vocabulary>counter for bundles</vocabulary>. Put this on a number, and you have "1 bundle" or "2 bundles" or even three, oh my!

Using the <kanji>grasp</kanji> meaning of 把 and combining it with <kanji>grip</kanji>, you can tell you're grasping at something and then gripping it. I usually grasp then grip at things flying at me, which makes this word mean <vocabulary>grasp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>understand</vocabulary>.

To <kanji>carry</kanji> you and <kanji>transport</kanji> you. That's a form of <vocabulary>transport</vocabulary>. Could also be a <vocabulary>carriage</vocabulary>, which is also a form of transport.

Things that <kanji>transport</kanji> and <kanji>send</kanji> you places are forms of <vocabulary>transportation</vocabulary>.

搬送 is most often used in medical contexts to refer to the transportation of patients.
<kanji>Transport</kanji> and <kanji>exit</kanji> these goods from here (by transporting them). Take it away. It's time to <vocabulary>carry out</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>cave</kanji> is a cave with sky (open space) in it. This is a <vocabulary>hollow</vocabulary>, but can also refer to a <vocabulary>cavity</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>cave</kanji> <kanji>hole</kanji> is a <vocabulary>cave</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>den</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>life</kanji> <kanji>horizon</kanji> is your life, which you're looking out over, all the way to the very end. This is <vocabulary>one's lifetime</vocabulary>, though it could also refer to <vocabulary>one's career</vocabulary>. Basically, at the end of it something dies.

We have to <kanji>examine</kanji> you during this <kanji>epidemic</kanji>... soooo, if you could come over here and just stay here for a long time, that'd be great. Yeah, it's kind of a <vocabulary>quarantine</vocabulary>, sorry about that.
To <kanji>excuse</kanji> yourself from the <kanji>epidemic</kanji>, you'll have to have <vocabulary>immunity</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>immunization</vocabulary> from the disease.

An <kanji>epidemic</kanji> of <kanji>sick</kanji>ness is going to come from an <vocabulary>infectious disease</vocabulary>. Perhaps a <vocabulary>plague</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>epidemic</vocabulary> of some kind?
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>threaten</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to threaten</vocabulary>.
You've seen that 飢える is "to starve." The noun version is <vocabulary>hunger</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>starvation</vocabulary>.

尽きる is "to be exhausted". 尽くす is when you're doing the exhausting of something, which makes it <vocabulary>to exhaust something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to run out</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>to devote oneself</vocabulary> to a certain cause.
This is the noun version of the kanji and has the same meaning as well: <vocabulary>coloring</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>regret</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to regret</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to mourn</vocabulary>.

Remember 殴る, which means "to punch"? Well, add on 合う and you've got <vocabulary>punches</vocabulary> that have <vocabulary>come together</vocabulary> with other punches. By "come together" I mean your fist is coming in contact with someone's face, and their fist is coming in contact with your kidneys. In other words, this is a <vocabulary>fistfight</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Punch</kanji> your way <kanji>into</kanji> a place, and you're launching a <vocabulary>raid</vocabulary>. 

殴り込み usually means a raid by gang members or delinquents, where they barge into someone's home or enemy territory to start a fight.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>accomplish</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to accomplish</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>hemp</kanji> <kanji>cloth</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hemp cloth</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>gloomy</kanji> <kanji>energy</kanji> has filled the room. This puts you in a <vocabulary>gloomy mood</vocabulary>. You are now <vocabulary>feeling downcast</vocabulary>.

This word is formal, so you'll mostly just see it in literature.

Who is the <kanji>chief</kanji> <kanji>father</kanji>? That's your <vocabulary>uncle</vocabulary>. And this uncle is the older brother of your mom or dad because he is the chief father. An uncle who is a younger brother of your parent is 叔父, which is another word for "uncle" you already know!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lamp</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to burn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be lit</vocabulary>. Just like what you'd do with a lamp.

If there is <kanji>nothing</kanji> <kanji>wicked</kanji> about your <kanji>spirit</kanji> at all, you are a going to be an <vocabulary>innocent</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>simple minded</vocabulary> person.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

You already learned 煮る, which is used for when you purposefully boil something. This verb, on the other hand, is intransitive, meaning that it refers to when something is getting boiled or cooked up, with no emphasis on who put the thing in the pot. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to be boiled</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be cooked</vocabulary>.
